fields.summary: Moving Existing Tags on Remote broken in (1.8.0.3) for mac

fields.description: When one tries to make a pull request by clicking local branch on sidebar nothing happens if it has no tracked remote branch. There could be a prompt suggesting to push a branch first and then there should standard pull request promt be shown.
fields.summary: Suggestion to push before pull request creation

fields.summary: Deadlock hang blocking main thread in Sourcetree

fields.description:
After a long time running a bunch of file descriptors are never released by SourceTree and eventually will prevent further FDs being created. 

This appears to be a recurrence of a very old problem which has been resurrected by a change for SRCTREE-1928.
fields.summary: Running out of file descriptors after long time open

fields.description: Having the option to show/hide the diff panel on demand would provide a much simplified UI, especially for users who prefer to use an external diff tool.
fields.summary: Add option to hide internal diff panel

fields.description:
SourceTree does an excellent job of visualizing and managing branches in a single repository. But when working with multiple repos, you end up with many windows and it's very cluttered.

My idea is to offer a simpler view (along the lines of GitBox) of your repository list in the main window, along with the ability to switch repos without having to open new windows. Maybe this could be accomplished with a tab for each repo, or maybe it's as simple as showing only the repo you selected in the bookmark list.

For users like me who work with multiple repos, this would increase the usability of SourceTree.

On a sidenote, I'm not sure why this is called a Bookmark list. This is, to my understanding, the list of the repos you are managing with SourceTree, so why not call it Repositories?
fields.summary: Dock Bookmarks panel + open new repo using same window

fields.description:
Quite often I'm looking at the diff pane for a file in some old commit and something gets refreshed by SourceTree that causes the selection to jump to the first file in the commit.
It would be excellent if the currently displayed commit/file/hunk/line/scroll-position stayed unaffected during such refreshes.
I'm not sure exactly what ST is refreshing. Sometimes it looks like nothing was really refreshed (at least all the remotes and local branches look the same) but it still does this unwanted reset on the file list and diff pane.
fields.summary: Upon automatic refreshes the current file and position is lost

fields.description:
Trying to revert a merge commit appears to require extra flags. I get the below error.

error: Commit 9630e8dcb8f2a1cc656097f8cce35e2c1a268dda is a merge but no -m option was given.
fatal: revert failed
Completed with errors, see above

My Sourcetree version is 1.6.2.2
fields.summary: Reverting merge commits give an error

fields.description:
Ensure that file/folder selections from subtree sheet only ever use relative paths and check that it's relative to the users' repository directory. Anything else is 'illegal'.

This draws from SRCTREE-2000

Marked as major as the selector on external volumes will select the absolute path instead of a relative path as shown in the linked issue.
fields.summary: Subtree path validity checks (relative/absolute)

fields.description:
Reported by a user on email, since a few versions ago (probably since the upgrade of the Xcode SDK to 10.8+) the commit text view has had Smart Quotes and Smart Dashes enable by default (right-click, Substitution menu). This cases a double-dash and quotes to be converted to extended characters which can cause problems on other platforms. 

While the user can disable these options, they are not remembered. 

This is exactly the same as the spell checking option in the commit text dialog, which is currently remembered. Rather than adding more options here, the best thing to do is to disable these options by default instead, since for a commit message you don't really want automatic substitution with special characters.
fields.summary: Automatic quote & dash substitution should be disabled for commit view

fields.description:
Reported by a user on email, since a few versions ago (probably since the upgrade of the Xcode SDK to 10.8+) the commit text view has had Smart Quotes and Smart Dashes enable by default (right-click, Substitution menu). This cases a double-dash and quotes to be converted to extended characters which can cause problems on other platforms. 

While the user can disable these options, they are not remembered.

Rather than adding more options here, the best thing to do is to disable these options by default instead, since for a commit message you don't really want automatic substitution with special characters.
fields.summary: Automatic quote & dash substitution should be disabled for commit view
Sourcetree Fails on Password When Cloning To Submodule

fields.description: When I'm on the commit dialog I want to use the keyboard to select the files. I can do this in TortoiseHg but hitting spacebar.
fields.summary: Hitting spacebar should select an item in the commit dialog

fields.description:
To perform a 'git rebase -i <rebase_target>' in SourceTree, I select the node representing rebase_target in a graph, then select the right in its contextual menu.

This menu is either labelled incorrectly or is very confusing. It should be 'rebase children of <head> interactively...', rather than 'rebase children of <rebase_target> interactively...', because I'm not trying to rebase <rebase_target>, but rather to rebase _onto_ it.
fields.summary: 'Rebase interactively' is labelled in a misleading way

fields.description:
My git project is connected to many remotes with hundreds of people committing on a regular basis. I don't need to see anyone else's feature branches very often, so I keep "Hide remote branches" turned on. However, any time I click a local branch, SourceTree switches this setting to "Show remote branches".

Repro steps:
# Click a local branch in the left pane
# Select "Hide remote branches"
# Click a different local branch in the left pane

Actual outcome:
"Show remote branches" is selected, and remote branches now clutter my commit history.

Desired outcome:
"Hide remote branches" remains selected, and my commit history remains relevant.
fields.summary: Don't automatically show remote branches when browsing local branches

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to see which characters within a line have changed. This would be especially useful when performing changes such as trimming trailing whitespace. In cases like this, the diff shows two apparently identical lines, one in red and one in green. Many diffing apps, such as Kaleidoscope and GitHub for Mac, highlight the whitespace that was changed, usually with a slightly different background color.
fields.summary: Sub-line diffs

fields.description: Add squash, onto, and rejoin options to subtree
fields.summary: Add squash, onto, and rejoin options to subtree

fields.description:
I'm switching from submodules to subtrees. To do this, I've created a topic branch and done the work in there. To get everything working properly, I had to delete the submodule folders entirely from disk. Once I have the subtrees set up in my branch, I can't checkout to move back and forth between my topic branch and the master branch because once I have the submodule re-established, they end up leaving their files as untracked files when trying to switch back to my subtree branch and I have to go and clean them up off of disk again.

It seems like in GITs view, it starts with no untracked/modified files, so it is fine with the checkout to the new branch with subtrees in place of submodules, but once it switches its view to that with subtrees, then all the submodule-related stuff appears as untracked files that would get overwritten. So, considered strictly from the end-user's perspective, I see that my working tree is clean, so I expect to be able to switch from this to any arbitrary branch.
fields.summary: Switching submodule to subtree requires manual interventions...

fields.description:
Scrolling from side to side or up and down when looking at diffs gets super bizarre when you're looking at sourceTree on an external monitor that is non-retina while using a Retina MBP. 

Please see attached video for what this looks like on the external monitor. Looks 100% as expected when on the retina screen of the laptop itself.
fields.summary: Retina MacBookPro + Non-Retina external display = Wacky Scrolling issues

fields.description:
Tool tips shown for left sidebar items (e.g. stash names) are truncated to the same width as the currently-visible table cell, thus making them of no value. 

Frequently, a stash name is long enough that it is truncated in the left sidebar. In such a case, it is natural for the user to mouse-over the cell in order to seek a tool tip describing the name in full. This does not work properly, leaving the stash name indiscernible unless one manually drags the split view to reveal its full width.

See the attached images.
fields.summary: Tool tips in sidebar are truncated or completely absent

fields.description:
(I first filed this issue on the QnA site: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/243982/sourcetree-doesn-t-refresh-files-in-the-working-tree; I got feedback from Kieran Senior that I should file it as a bug.)

I've been using SourceTree on Mac for a few months and I've been really happy with it.

But recently something happened and SourceTree stopped auto-refreshing the "Files in the working tree" panel. So now if I change some code file and save it, then flip over to SourceTree, I don't see the change reflected in that panel and I'm forced to take some manual action to force-refresh it.

I tried upgrading to SourceTree 1.7 and again to 1.8. That didn't help.

I tried going to Settings - Advanced and making sure that these checkboxes are checked:

* Automatically Refresh (if disabled you must manually refresh this repository)

* Refresh remote status in the background (if enabled in global preferences)

That didn't help either.

I've found that any of the following actions can serve as a "force refresh":

* Restarting SourceTree

* Unchecking and rechecking the checkboxes mentioned above

* Flipping the dropdown from "Show Pending" to "Show Untracked" and back.

Is there some other setting I'm not aware of? Is this a known bug? Is there a keyboard shortcut to force refresh the "Files in the working tree" panel?
thanks!

--S
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't refresh files in the working tree

fields.description:
The mercurial package 'hgext' has moved up a directory. We check for mercurial's validity when specifying system mercurial by checking for this folder in the site-packages/mercurial folder, where it won't exist. Need to find out what version of mercurial this move happened from so we can make sure they're supported appropriately.

http://selenic.com/hg/file/209e04a06467/setup.py#l420

Original issue here: https://support.atlassian.com/browse/STSP-899
fields.summary: Recent versions of mercurial won't work in SourceTree

fields.description: This error pops up randomly.
fields.summary: 'git status' failed with code 128:'fatal: index file smaller than expected '

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to right click a pushed commit and view the diff in Bitbucket or GitHub when project is hosted there. Examples:

https://bitbucket.org/evgenyg/wiki/commits/fb1334975d28db58dc4068fe1599e40e7194e7ab

https://github.com/atmos/atmos.github.io/commit/963673f8beee3572280666772ab5ba46ca8da3d4
fields.summary: Right click commit => View diff in Bitbucket / GitHub

fields.description:
When an update for SourceTree is found, the "Updating SourceTree" popup window remains overlaid on top of other applications while the update is in progress. 

It is very annoying to have a popup from an application that is temporarily unusable plastered over everything else.
fields.summary: "Updating SourceTree" Window Stays on Top of Other Application Windows

Hi 
This issue comes on my mac, since 2 or 3 months, mainly on 10.9.
It appears a bit randomly, but come with an project window clone from github.

After opened a github-cloned window, left until it become idled, while reactive it, a dialog about keychain asking if user is willing to grant permission to sourcetree to use github entry will appear.
If  YES/ALWAYS YES are clicked, the sourcetree got a chance to hanged...
And forcely-stopping is the only solution to get it back..

The error log are attached, it seems a recursive action has been performed..

Since I am not native English speaker, if you find any word is unable to understood, feel free to contact and ask what it means directly :)
And the above means this issue may happen only in non-ascii, if you have not tested it before.

fields.description:
This is a regression, it used to work fine in 1.7.2 (not sure about newer ones).

Right-clicking a non-merged branch and not turning on the "force delete" checkbox still deletes a branch. :( If one's used to SourceTree not allowing to do that, one can easily remove a non-merged branch, leading to loss of data.

I think it's a serious issue.
fields.summary: A non-merged branch is deleted even in the "force delete" checkbox is off

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Clone this repository in SourceTree: https://bitbucket.org/jennings/sourcetree-subtree-does-not-link-on-first-try
2. Click Repository --> Add/Link Subtree
3. Provide a remote URL and branch, and use "sub" as the local relative path. Click OK, then click Create Link.

Expected Result:

The subtree should now be visible in the left column under the heading "Subtrees"

Actual Result:

The subtree does not appear (the heading is not collapsed). If I quit SourceTree, then immediately repeat steps 2 and 3, the subtree does appear in the left column.

I did a diff of the .git/sourcetreeconfig file between each step, and it does not have the subtree's information written into it until after quitting SourceTree and immediately trying to link the subtree again.
fields.summary: Subtree will not link on the first try

fields.description:
This bug makes the synthetic history generated by SourceTree incompatible with other subtree users. The root cause seems to be an extra "-n\n" in the commit messages generated by the embedded version of Git.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Clone this repository: https://bitbucket.org/jennings/sourcetree-subtree-commit-message-bug
2. Set SourceTree to use the embedded Git (version 1.8.4.2)
3. Use "Add/Link Subtree" to link the "sub" directory with a remote repository.
4. Push the subtree.
5. Set SourceTree to use the system version of Git (tested with version 1.8.5)
6. Push the subtree.

Results:

The subtree created using the embedded Git has a head commit ID of 6e92039. The subtree created using the system Git has a head commit ID of 329f350. Resultant repos can be seen here:

https://bitbucket.org/jennings/sourcetree-subtree-commit-message-bug-embedded
https://bitbucket.org/jennings/sourcetree-subtree-commit-message-bug-system

Expected result:

Both branch head commit IDs should be 329f350.
fields.summary: Pushing a subtree creates incorrect commit history using embedded git version

fields.description:
After upgrading to version 1.8.0.2 from the pervious version i am having trouble checking out a remote git-svn branch.

Error message:

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree checkout -b feature-lockscreen-tracking --track feature-infinite-scroll 
fatal: Cannot setup tracking information; starting point 'feature-infinite-scroll' is not a branch.
Completed with errors, see above


This works as expected (from the command line)

Blakes-MacBook-Pro:perk-api blake$ git checkout -b feature-infinite-scroll feature-infinite-scroll
Switched to a new branch 'feature-infinite-scroll'


I believe this may have something to do with the updated embedded git version as described here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19712735/git-svn-cannot-setup-tracking-information-starting-point-is-not-a-branch
fields.summary: Git-Svn broken when checking out a remote

fields.description:
See attached screenshot:

I was expecting double clicking on "origin/cal-259-ios-donotdisturb" in the branch history view would move my local cal-259-ios-donotdisturb forward to that commit.

Instead it offers to check out that branch again, and then fails as shown in the second screenshot because (as expected) the branch already exists.

I think it this case it would be best to just essentially do the same as a 'pull' would do, and bring the local branch up to date with origin? [at least in this case; I'm less sure what it should do if the local branch has diverged from origin - maybe show the pull dialogue in that case?]

I can't decide if this is a bug or an improvement; I picked bug on the grounds that the operation that it tries to do in this case will, I think, never succeed.
fields.summary: Double clicking on the commit for the head of branch doesn't move the working copy to that commit when local branch behind origin

fields.description:
After upgrading to SourceTree 1.8.0.2, pulling from a git-svn remote no longer works.

Error:
{code}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree svn rebase 
"get_tz_offset" is not exported by the Git module
Can't continue after import errors at /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/lib/perl5/site_perl/Git/SVN.pm line 25
BEGIN failed--compilation aborted at /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/lib/perl5/site_perl/Git/SVN.pm line 25.
Compilation failed in require at /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/libexec/git-core/git-svn line 25.
BEGIN failed--compilation aborted at /Applications/SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/git_local/libexec/git-core/git-svn line 25.
Completed with errors, see above
{code}

The _Settings_ in SourceTree don't show my remote anymore, and when pulling or pushing, the field with the remote is empty (see screenshots).

The {{.git/config}} file looks like this:
{code}
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = true
	bare = false
	logallrefupdates = true
	ignorecase = true
[svn-remote "svn"]
	url = https://server/repos/svn
	fetch = foo/trunk:refs/remotes/svn/trunk
	branches = foo/branches/*:refs/remotes/svn/*
	tags = foo/tags/*:refs/remotes/svn/tags/*
{code}

Using a command line Git client (v1.8.4.3) works fine without any issues. Selecting this Git client in SourceTree also works fine. The embedded v1.8.4.2 client seems to be causing the issue.
fields.summary: Error "get_tz_offset" is not exported by the Git module after upgrade to SourceTree 1.8.0.2

fields.description:
When a user goes to switch branches in Sourcetree, there is a confirmation dialog that is presented.

This dialog has the text "Confirm Branch Switch" with a checkbox that reads, "Discard local changes".

The issue that myself, and many others have experienced:  When you display that dialog every time someone wants to switch a branch *regardless of whether or not there are any local changes to discard* then all of your users become desensitized to this dialog completely.  

We end up clicking OK out of habit/routine, and if you use this tool long enough, you're eventually going to discard something you actually don't want to.  This is extremely frustrating to the user.  

My suggested solution:  Only display the dialog if there is actually work to discard.  The dialog then becomes a legitimate warning that the user will pay attention to.

This product is great, and I think this simple fix will benefit all users.
fields.summary: UX -- Only display "Confirm Branch Switch" dialog when user has local changes to lose.

fields.description:
When performing a graft onto another branch with changes that result in merge conflicts, after choosing within sourcetree which file to use, sourcetree saves the resulting file as filename.orig, and leaves the original filename.ext as it is, resulting in the working copy as a 'successful' merge using the old file, and a brand new untracked file of filename.orig.

This obviously isn't right, and it's a bit worrying to be honest...
fields.summary: When grafting one branch changeset to another branch, resolving merge conflicts confuses .orig and the new file

fields.description:
The default commit message generated when combining commits in a rebase doesn't always seem helpful:

Sourcetree seems to pick the newest commit to use as the primary bit of the commit message - I'm not sure about other people's workflows, but in mine the oldest commit almost always contains the main meat of what happened, and the later commits were tweaks/fixups/bug fixes.

It'd also be helpful to leave a blank line (or even some kind of delimiter) in between each commit message in the new message, so it's easier to see where one commit message ends and the next begins.

It would be great to also make the commit message edit window a bit bigger for the merging commits case (or maybe all cases?); at least in Version 1.7.4.1 on mac os x you can only see about 4 lines of text and there doesn't seem to be any way to resize it.

(previous mentioned as comments on SRCTREE-1968, but raised as a new suggestion as it's not really quite related to that change)
fields.summary: Improvements to commit messages handling when rebasing

fields.description:
We use issue number from Jira as the start of feature branch names. As you can see branch AC-1000 comes before branch AC-893 in the sidebar. 

*Solution*
Make the sorting of branches with numbers in them smarter.
fields.summary: Sorting of branches

fields.description:
It seems that the latest update to 1.7.4.1 broke the SVN support of SourceTree. When I add a remote SVN repository I get the response "This is not a valid source path / URL". The text after pressing Details are attached.

The links work fine with another SVN client, also with previous versions there was no issue.
I am still having some SVN repositories that work fine in the bookmark list. However I cannot add them again due to this error.
fields.summary: Clone Repository from a remote SVN repository yields error

fields.description:
This is a pretty rare occurrence I'm sure, but I have a local git repo which has 2 remotes setup. The first is an SVN Bridge where the SVN repostiory is behind a firewall requiring VPN access while the second is a git repo on my company's Stash instance. Today I was trying to pull changes from a remote git branch into my local and I could not because it couldn't reach the SVN repository. I'm not quite sure why it is trying to talk to the SVN repo when I've selected my Git repo as the remote host. This works fine if I connect to the VPN and pushing doesn't have any problems. The message is below and I've replaced the SVN URLs.

{quote}
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree fetch Stash 

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree svn fetch 
RA layer request failed: Unable to connect to a repository at URL '<<SVN_REPO>>': OPTIONS of '<<SVN_REPO>>': Could not resolve hostname `<<SVN_HOST>>': Host not found (<<SVN_HOST>>) at /usr/local/git/lib/perl5/site_perl/Git/SVN.pm line 148.

Completed with errors, see above
{quote}
fields.summary: Cannot Pull from remote if local repository has a remote svn it can't connect to.

fields.description: It would be great to have a "Stage All" hotkey. I often type down the commit message quickly and hit the commit button via Cmd+Enter to Commit but staging the files always requires mouse interaction. It would be great if I could just hit a simple key combo like in Git Gui and stage all modified files directly from the commit message window.
fields.summary: Hotkey for "Stage all"

fields.description:
In general it seems that updates that are made in the repository are not synced in SourceTree. For example, if I make a change in a file, I don't see that change in SourceTree. Also, when I switch branches on the command line, SourceTree still shows that I'm on the old branch. New stashes made on the command line don't appear in SourceTree, etc. 

Only after restarting SourceTree the status of the repository is up to date.

fields.description:
Although checking and unchecking the "Select All" checkbox causes all list items to be checked and unchecked, as expected, the state of the "Select All" checkbox is not affected by the checked states of the list entries.

To reproduce:
1. Ensure that "select all files when selecting commit" is enabled in SourceTree>Preferences>General.
2. Choose "Commit" in a Mercurial project with uncommitted changes
3. Note the state of the "Select All" checkbox

Expected results:
Since all items are selected by default, the state of "Select All" in Step 3 should be selected too.

Actual results:
The "Select All" checkbox is not selected, even though all the items in the list are selected.

Notes:
Because "Select All" is a checkbox and not a button, it ought to display state as well as have an action when you push it. Right now, it does appear to display state, but that state is not derived. Instead, it is an independent boolean which starts out as false. This is misleading (as it does not reflect the collective state of the list) and annoying (because it needs to be pushed twice to disable all the list members).
fields.summary: "Select All" checkbox state is not affected by checkboxes in the list it affects

fields.summary: No GPG-Keys available for commit signing

fields.description:
To reproduce:

1. Open or create a repo with more than 100 commits.
2. Pick the "Jump To revision/changeset" option from the "Jump To" drop-down and enter "10", to try to jump to revision 10. Hit enter.

What should happen: SourceTree should jump to revision 10.

What happens: SourceTree jumps to the most recent revision whose revision # starts with "10" (100, 109, etc). There is no workaround to get that dialog to jump you to the correct revision.
fields.summary: "Jump To" doesn't handle revision #s properly

fields.description:
For the purposes of integrating into other apps (like text editors), it'd be very handy to be able to call SourceTree with the path to a file and a command name and have it pop open a new window showing it.

Often I'll be in an editor (like Sublime Text 2) and want to bring up a blame, log or even external diff window. Currently if I've recently edited the file, I can switch over to my space with SourceTree and select the file and do the command (a bit annoying but not horrible). But if I haven't edited the file I need to switch to Show All and search for the file first. Often times I'll edit the file temporarily by adding a space just to make it easier to find quickly in SourceTree.

Having the ability to launch a window right from the CLI tools would make it trivial for me to create an extension for Sublime (or pretty much any other editor) which just launches SourceTree directly for the correct file. Ideally if the repo was already open it wouldn't launch a whole other copy of SourceTree but even that would be preferable to the current workflow IMO.
fields.summary: Launch Log/Blame/Diff window via CLI for a file

fields.description: Currently if the user specifies a bad GPG location SourceTree won't question it. Currently SourceTree displays the attached image when trying to enable GPG on a repository. Instead, display a message saying GPG couldn't be found at location X with suggestions for fixes and/or a link to the built-in documents which do assist the user.

fields.description:
Developers might add Tag in the commit log, which looks like #12345 or #hash, can be used to indicate an entry ID in external system. Could you please consider creating link for these tags?

SourceTree could add an option in the Preferences window as following text:

http://mydomain/issue?id=__PLACEHOLDER__
for #12345, __PLACEHOLDER__ is 12345

Then users can access the external system through clicking the generated link.

Thank you guys!
fields.summary: Create link for tag in commit logs

fields.description:
see https://github.com/aanand/git-up

in my daily work I almost always want my local git tracking branches to be on par with the remote branches if I didn't diverge on them. Especially when using git-flow i want to make sure that the develop branch is on par with the remote branch before merging.

however, doing the keep up game with mulitple branches is very cumbersome:
- switch branch
- pull and fast forward (which is especially unsettling as i have do not fast forward for regular merges on)
- repeat for all branches
- switch back to the branch i want to git-flow end

having a button that fast-forwards all my local git tracking branches to the most recent state of the default remote would be awesome!

Linked from AAC: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/231609/sourcetree-cpu-usage-and-slowness

Reporter: Kevin Powick

Based on the troubleshooting CAC page here's what we know so far. Customer to provide the rest of the details:

1. Embedded Hg 2.2.2
2. iMac Quad Core i5 @ 2.8GHz. 12GB main memory. Unaware of disk space, customer to provide.

fields.summary: Performance issues

fields.description:
There is a problem with cherry-pick. If you select multiple commits and select cherry-pick sometimes there is an error.

The explanation:

If you select multiple commits and click in cherry-pick the sourcetree does not apply the selected commits in the correct order.

So, if a commit is dependent of another (such a bugfix of a bugfix) may occur a problem that the second be apply before the first, causing conflict error.

The above behavior explains why it works when cherry-picking individual commits. In this case, the user will apply the commits manually, one by one, in the right order and will not get conflict errors.

So the bug is that sourcetree not apply the selected commits in the right order.

This problem may be related to other threads that do not explain the cause of the problem.
fields.summary: conflict when cherry-picking multiple commits

fields.description:
SourceTree used to show the local HEAD in the list of local branches on the sidebar on the left but it doesn't anymore.

SourceTree only shows HEAD in the sidebar if you're not on a branch,  that is, you're on a detached HEAD - this was possible by double-clicking a commit that's not at the end of a branch.
fields.summary: SourceTree Does Not Show HEAD Under Branches When Detached

fields.description: The hg_local script uses "/usr/bin/env python" to run python. This causes problems if the default version of python is python 3.x (mercurial doesn't work with py3k). I think that GUI apps ignored the $PATH setting of the user in OS X 10.8, but in OS X 10.9, it seems to use my $PATH and picks /opt/local/bin/python, which is a symlink to python3.3. Just hard-coding python2.7 might be an acceptable solution, but with a bit of extra code you could set it up so that python2.7 is only used as a fallback if python corresponds to python3.
fields.summary: SourceTree should fall back on python2.7 if "python" corresponds to python 3.x
